g.text: Uncertainty in downscaling future climate projections due to weather generators.
climate index, the proximity of different GCM
RCP combinations was assessed by approximating the area of
overlap of the probability density distributions of the index values obtained with each WG. The results summa-
return a quite high likelihood (0.7) to obtain the same value for different indices regardless of the
RCP combination. This likelihood was indeed higher than the average resemblance of generated to refer-
0.5). While a strong dependence of results on geographical location (site-specific) was somewhat
) was that results from different GCMs and RCPs tended to cluster
by WG (more than by site). Given the influence of the different WGs on climate scenarios, the additional uncer-
tainty that may result from the interaction between generation (WGs) and projections (GCMs and RCPs) was ana-
lyzed. A series of nonparametric robust rank order ANOVA tests was thus conducted to assess the effect of different
, and their interactions) on each climate index calculated on future series (Fig.
Two main patterns arose: some indices were strongly dependent from all the driving factors (red columns in
), whereas some factors affected most of the indices (red rows). Besides, some indices, like the cold spell
duration index (CSDI), were not significantly driven (
0.05) by any factor. Evapotranspiration- and rain-related
indices (i.e., SAM and rx1day) were the most affected by the factors considered (as highlighted by thick red col-
(red rows), appeared to be the most influential for the
Probability to have the same density distribution for different climate indices. Color lines indicate
weather generators (C: CLIMAK; L: LARS-WG; W: WeaGETS) whereas line styles correspond to sites
) Overlapping areas of probability density distributions of different monthly-based
climate indices (radial axes, labelled in Supplementary Information) derived from different WGs for each
RCP combination. Solid black line indicates perfect fit of different combination GCM
generated by the same WG for the same Site. The closer the lines to one, the smaller the difference between
) Overall density similarity across indices for GCM
-value for factors affecting the indices (described in Supplementary Information) derived from
the analysis of generated future projections. Color scale is the same as in Fig.
